None of those arguments against net neutrality were actually about net neutrality. They were about data hogging. Nothing in that discussion said ISPs ought to be able to sniff your packets and differentiate service according to the meaning of your data. If the ISPs switch to a pay-for-what-you-use model, most users would see lower bills. Instead, they want a pay-big-for-unlimited-service for light users, and a not-really-unlimited-service for heavy users, and eventually a we're-messing-with-you-because-we-can service for any uses they disapprove of.

Should the government...NO!  Government is violence-backed coercion used to benefit a select few at the expense of the rest. The Patriot Act was not Patriotic, the Affordable Care Act was not affordable...and Net Neutrality is NOT neutral. It is a way for large companies and their army of lawyers, lobbyists and their hired bureaucrats and politicians to control YOU and the Internet. Do you really want Donald Trump or Barack Obama or the next person in line to be in charge of anything? If an ISP doesn't provide you with what you want at a fair price, go somewhere else. A government bill will only solidify the monopoly grasp these corporate empires desire.

None of the ISPs were doing what Net Neutrality is supposed to prevent becasue it would have been market suicide. All Net Neutrality did was make it harder for smaller competitors to enter the market who would have added to the risk if an ISP decided to violate the principle of net neutrality.

Net Neutrality is only required because most consumers do not have a genuine choice of ISP.

In a situation where there is a non retailer infrastructure where everyone can choose between hundreds of ISPs (such as in Australia's NBN) - then Net Neutrality isn't that important.
